Title: Association between maternal exposure to perfluoroalkyl and polyfluoroalkyl substances and risks of adverse pregnancy outcomes: A systematic review and meta-analysis
Authors: Zhuoma Deji, Peng Liu, Xin Wang, Xin Zhang, Yuehua Luo, Zhenzhen Huang
Supporting quotes for "Review type claim:
- "systematic review and meta-analysis"
  - "The systematic review and meta-analysis was performed according to the general principles recommended in the Meta-Analysis of Observational Studies in Epidemiology consensus statement and Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Review and Meta-analyses (PRISMA) criteria (Fig. 1"
  - "A random-effects model meta-analysis was performed to calculate pooled effect estimates and investigate the associations between PFASs and miscarriage, stillbirth or preterm birth."
Reasoning for "Review type claimed":
The authors claim that this is a "systematic review and meta-analysis" of the association between maternal exposure to perfluoroalkyl and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFASs) and risks of adverse pregnancy outcomes. This is evident from the following quotes:
"The systematic review and meta-analysis was performed according to the general principles recommended in the Meta-Analysis of Observational Studies in Epidemiology consensus statement and Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Review and Meta-analyses (PRISMA) criteria (Fig. 1 )."
"Twenty-one studies evaluating the influence of PFASs exposure and risks of adverse pregnancy outcomes were included in this meta-analysis."
"A random-effects model meta-analysis was performed to calculate pooled effect estimates and investigate the associations between PFASs and miscarriage, stillbirth or preterm birth."
The authors clearly state that this is a systematic review and meta-analysis of the association between maternal PFASs exposure and adverse pregnancy outcomes.

Title: Early-Life Exposure to Per-and Poly-Fluorinated Alkyl Substances and Growth, Adiposity, and Puberty in Children: A Systematic Review
Authors: Yun Jeong Lee, Hae Woon, Hwa Young Kim, Yoon-Jung Choi, Young Ah Lee, Alberto Mantovani
Supporting quotes for "Review type claim:
- "This systematic review was reported according to Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Review and meta-Analysis (PRISMA) guidelines (14)."
  - "We searched MEDLINE, EMBASE, Web of Science, and Scopus on May 21, 2021 with the keywords shown in Supplementary Table 1 . The selection criteria were 1) cohort studies or casecontrol studies which investigated the effects of PFAS on growth, adiposity, or puberty in children and adolescents, 2) primary research articles in English and published in peer-reviewed journals."
  - "A total of 1534 articles were identified in the database. After excluding duplications (n = 993), 542 records were screened (Supplementary Figure 1 ). These articles were screened by title (376 were excluded), abstract (73 were excluded) and full text (3 were excluded). The reasons for exclusion are shown in Supplementary Figure 1 . The 90 studies included in this review were published between November 2007 and July 2021."
Reasoning for "Review type claimed":
The authors state that this is a "systematic review" in the abstract and throughout the paper. This is evident from the following quotes:
"This systematic review was reported according to Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Review and meta-Analysis (PRISMA) guidelines (14)."
"A total of 1534 articles were identified in the database. After excluding duplications (n = 993), 542 records were screened (Supplementary Figure 1 ). These articles were screened by title (376 were excluded), abstract (73 were excluded) and full text (3 were excluded). The reasons for exclusion are shown in Supplementary Figure 1 . The 90 studies included in this review were published between November 2007 and July 2021."
"We searched MEDLINE, EMBASE, Web of Science, and Scopus on May 21, 2021 with the keywords shown in Supplementary Table 1 . The selection criteria were 1) cohort studies or casecontrol studies which investigated the effects of PFAS on growth, adiposity, or puberty in children and adolescents, 2) primary research articles in English and published in peer-reviewed journals."

In order to provide a comprehensive summary of the studies of preterm birth and environmental chemicals to date, a list of exposures of interest was first compiled from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's Fourth National Exposure Report (CDC, 2009).

Title: Human exposure pathways to poly-and perfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) from indoor media: A systematic review
Authors: Nicole M Deluca, Jeffrey M Minucci, Ashley Mullikin, Rachel Slover, Elaine A Cohen Hubal, Adrian Covaci, B S T R A C T
Supporting quotes for "Review type claim:
- "This systematic review (SR) synthesizes evidence for exposure from indoor residential pathways to inform understanding of variability in serum PFAS levels in the general population from sources other than drinking water and diet."
  - "This systematic review used a modified version of the risk of bias tool for epidemiology studies described in EPA's Systematic Review Protocol for the PFBA, PFHxA, PFHxS, PFNA, and PFDA IRIS Assessments (U.S. EPA, 2019) to evaluate each study."
  - "The methods used in this systematic review were previously described in detail in a peer-reviewed protocol (DeLuca et al., 2021) and are based on those described in U.S. EPA's Systematic Review Protocol for the PFBA, PFHxA, PFHxS, PFNA, and PFDA IRIS Assessments (U.S. EPA, 2019) and the Navigation Guide (Woodruff et al., 2011;Woodruff and Sutton, 2014;Johnson et al., 2014;Lam et al., 2016)."
Reasoning for "Review type claimed":
The authors claim that this is a systematic review, as evidenced by the following quotes:
"This systematic review (SR) synthesizes evidence for exposure from indoor residential pathways to inform understanding of variability in serum PFAS levels in the general population from sources other than drinking water and diet."
"The methods used in this systematic review were previously described in detail in a peer-reviewed protocol (DeLuca et al., 2021) and are based on those described in U.S. EPA's Systematic Review Protocol for the PFBA, PFHxA, PFHxS, PFNA, and PFDA IRIS Assessments (U.S. EPA, 2019) and the Navigation Guide (Woodruff et al., 2011;Woodruff and Sutton, 2014;Johnson et al., 2014;Lam et al., 2016)."
"This systematic review used a modified version of the risk of bias tool for epidemiology studies described in EPA's Systematic Review Protocol for the PFBA, PFHxA, PFHxS, PFNA, and PFDA IRIS Assessments (U.S. EPA, 2019) to evaluate each study."

Title: Legacy and emerging pollutants in Latin America: A critical review of occurrence and levels in environmental and food samples
Authors: Cristina Marília,  Oliveira Souza, Bruno Alves Rocha, Joseph A Adeyemi, Martí Nadal, José Luis Domingo, Fernando Barbosa, Damià Barceló
Supporting quotes for "Review type claim:
- "The current review encompassed both organic and inorganic pollutants."
  - "The current review intends to cover the literature data on the observed levels of the most representative legacy and EPs in several environmental and food samples."
  - "this review compiles the current knowledge of the levels of different classes of EPs and legacy pollutants in food and environmental matrices (soil, sediment, water, and air) of the LA region."
Reasoning for "Review type claimed":
The authors claim that this is a "critical review" of the literature on legacy and emerging pollutants in Latin America. This is evident from the following quotes:
"The current review intends to cover the literature data on the observed levels of the most representative legacy and EPs in several environmental and food samples."
"The current review encompassed both organic and inorganic pollutants."
"This review compiles the current knowledge of the levels of different classes of EPs and legacy pollutants in food and environmental matrices (soil, sediment, water, and air) of the LA region."
The authors explicitly state that this is a "critical review" of the literature on legacy and emerging pollutants in Latin America.

Title: Organic Contaminants in Chinese Sewage Sludge: A Meta-Analysis of the Literature of the Past 30 Years
Authors: Xiang-Zhou Meng, Arjun K Venkatesan, Yi-Lin Ni, Joshua C Steele, Ling-Ling Wu, Anders Bignert, Åke Bergman, Rolf U Halden
Supporting quotes for "Review type claim:
- "Using literature from the past 30 years (N = 159), we conducted a meta-analysis of organic contaminants (OCs) in Chinese sludge."
  - "In this study, we present the first systematic review and a meta-analysis of OCs in Chinese sludge based on the literature published over the past 30 years."
  - "The objectives were to (i) examine the temporal and spatial distributions of all previous work, (ii) reveal the identity and concentration of important and abundant OCs in Chinese sludge, and (iii) assess the potential need for conducting a Chinese national sewage sludge survey."
Reasoning for "Review type claimed":
The authors claim that this is a "meta-analysis" of the literature on organic contaminants in Chinese sewage sludge over the past 30 years. This is evident from the following quotes:
"Using literature from the past 30 years (N = 159), we conducted a meta-analysis of organic contaminants (OCs) in Chinese sludge."
"In this study, we present the first systematic review and a meta-analysis of OCs in Chinese sludge based on the literature published over the past 30 years."
"The objectives were to (i) examine the temporal and spatial distributions of all previous work, (ii) reveal the identity and concentration of important and abundant OCs in Chinese sludge, and (iii) assess the potential need for conducting a Chinese national sewage sludge survey."

Title: Perfluoroalkyl substances and lipid concentrations in the blood: A systematic review of epidemiological studies
Authors: Soon Hoe Ho, Stacy Xin, Hui Soh, Min Xian Wang, Janet Ong, Annabel Seah, Yvonne Wong, Zhanxiong Fang, Shuzhen Sim, Jue Tao Lim, C L E I N F O, Adrian Covaci
Supporting quotes for "Review type claim:
- "We took reference from the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) statement throughout the process (Liberati et al., 2009)."
  - "This systematic review aims to assess PFAS associations with low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL), high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL), total cholesterol (TC) and total triglyceride (TG) concentrations in human populations."
  - "We systematically searched four online databases, PubMed, Scopus, Embase, and Cochrane Library for relevant peer-reviewed English language articles published until July 2021."
Reasoning for "Review type claimed":
The authors claim that this is a systematic review, as evidenced by the following quotes:
"This systematic review aims to assess PFAS associations with low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL), high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL), total cholesterol (TC) and total triglyceride (TG) concentrations in human populations."
"We systematically searched four online databases, PubMed, Scopus, Embase, and Cochrane Library for relevant peer-reviewed English language articles published until July 2021."
"We took reference from the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) statement throughout the process (Liberati et al., 2009)."
The authors explicitly state that this is a systematic review, and they followed the PRISMA guidelines for conducting systematic reviews.

Title: The Association between ADHD and Environmental Chemicals-A Scoping Review
Authors: Sonja Moore, Laura Paalan, Lisa Melym, Andromachi Katsonouri, Marike Kolossa-Gehring, Hanna Tolonen
Supporting quotes for "Review type claim:
- "This is a scoping literature review [14], which summarizes epidemiological studies on the associations of ADHD and HBM4EU priority substances, or their possible associations, which justify further research."
  - "Literature searches were performed in PubMed in June-September 2020 and repeated in Spring 2021 to include any relevant new publications. The search used the terms "ADHD", "meta-analysis", or "review", and each of the HBM4EU priority substances separately. Additional searches were conducted with more general search terms, such as "environmental chemical" and "exposure". Only meta-analyses and review articles were included, as they provide more extensive evidence compared to individual studies."
Reasoning for "Review type claimed":
The authors state that this is a "scoping review" in the abstract and methods section:
"This is a scoping literature review [14], which summarizes epidemiological studies on the associations of ADHD and HBM4EU priority substances, or their possible associations, which justify further research."
"Literature searches were performed in PubMed in June-September 2020 and repeated in Spring 2021 to include any relevant new publications. The search used the terms "ADHD", "meta-analysis", or "review", and each of the HBM4EU priority substances separately. Additional searches were conducted with more general search terms, such as "environmental chemical" and "exposure". Only meta-analyses and review articles were included, as they provide more extensive evidence compared to individual studies."
The authors explicitly state that this is a scoping review, which aims to summarize the existing evidence from meta-analyses and review articles on the associations between ADHD and the HBM4EU priority chemicals.
